unnormalised: ## Aloo, Pyaaz, Tamatar and the Maths Behind It All!
normalised: Aloo, Pyaaz, Tamatar and the Maths Behind It All!

unnormalised: Hey everyone! So, recently I've been trying to be more mindful about my grocery shopping. You know, actually planning my meals instead of just grabbing whatever looks good at the *sabzi mandi*. And let me tell you, it's opened my eyes to a whole new world... a world of measurements!
normalised: Hey everyone! So, recently I've been trying to be more mindful about my grocery shopping. You know, actually planning my meals instead of just grabbing whatever looks good at the sabzi mandi. And let me tell you, it's opened my eyes to a whole new world... a world of measurements!

unnormalised: Seriously, who knew there was so much involved in buying something as simple as, say, potatoes? Before, I'd just ask the *sabziwala* for "do kilo aloo, bhaiya". Two kilos! Seemed straightforward enough. But now, I'm thinking about what *kind* of potatoes I need. Are they for *aloo gobi*? Then maybe slightly larger ones. Or for *aloo tikki*? Smaller, denser ones are better. And then the price per kg comes into play… it’s a whole calculation!
normalised: Seriously, who knew there was so much involved in buying something as simple as, say, potatoes? Before, I'd just ask the sabziwala for "two kilo aloo, bhaiya". Two kilos! Seemed straightforward enough. But now, I'm thinking about what kind of potatoes I need. Are they for aloo gobi? Then maybe slightly larger ones. Or for aloo tikki? Smaller, denser ones are better. And then the price per kilogram comes into play… it’s a whole calculation!

unnormalised: The other day, I needed onions for a big batch of biryani. The recipe called for "500g of sliced onions." Now, I could just eyeball it, but where’s the fun (and accuracy!) in that? So, I actually weighed them at the store. And you know what? 500g looks like a lot more than you think! Plus, prices vary depending on the size. Small onions might be cheaper per kg, but you need more of them. It's all about optimizing!
normalised: The other day, I needed onions for a big batch of biryani. The recipe called for "five hundred gram of sliced onions." Now, I could just eyeball it, but where’s the fun (and accuracy!) in that? So, I actually weighed them at the store. And you know what? five hundred gram looks like a lot more than you think! Plus, prices vary depending on the size. Small onions might be cheaper per kilogram, but you need more of them. It's all about optimizing!

unnormalised: Then there's the whole leafy greens situation. Spinach, *methi*, coriander... they’re always sold in *gaddis*, right? A *gaddi* of spinach might look big, but once you wash and chop it, it shrinks down to almost nothing! So, I've started estimating how many *gaddis* I need based on how many cups the recipe requires. Usually, 2 *gaddis* gives me about 3 cups of chopped spinach. But that depends on the *gaddi* size, doesn't it?

Usually, two gaddis gives me about three cups of chopped spinach. But that depends on the gaddi size, doesn't it?

unnormalised: And don’t even get me started on liquids! I was making rasam last week, and the recipe called for "1.5 liters of water". I only had a 1-liter measuring jug. Talk about feeling like a complete numbskull! Had to make multiple trips to the sink to measure it properly. I really should get a bigger jug. Or maybe just convert liters to milliliters… 1.5 liters is 1500 ml, right? Basic maths, but sometimes my brain just blanks out.
normalised: And don’t even get me started on liquids! I was making rasam last week, and the recipe called for "one point five liters of water". I only had a one-liter measuring jug. Talk about feeling like a complete numbskull! Had to make multiple trips to the sink to measure it properly. I really should get a bigger jug. Or maybe just convert liters to milliliters… one point five liters is one thousand five hundred milliliter, right? Basic maths, but sometimes my brain just blanks out.

unnormalised: Tomatoes are another tricky one. Some recipes call for "2 large tomatoes", others for "300g of chopped tomatoes". How do you reconcile those two? Especially when tomato sizes can vary so much! I usually weigh one tomato and then estimate how many I need to get close to the required weight. It's not perfect, but it's better than guessing! Yesterday, tomatoes were selling for ₹60 per kg, but if you bought 250 g, it was ₹20. Strange, but I went for it.
normalised: Tomatoes are another tricky one. Some recipes call for "two large tomatoes", others for "three hundred gram of chopped tomatoes". How do you reconcile those two? Especially when tomato sizes can vary so much! I usually weigh one tomato and then estimate how many I need to get close to the required weight. It's not perfect, but it's better than guessing! Yesterday, tomatoes were selling for rupee sixty per kilogram, but if you bought two hundred and fifty gram, it was rupee twenty. Strange, but I went for it.

unnormalised: I even saw someone buying green chilies in "pao", that's 250g, right? I usually just buy a small packet for ₹10 or ₹20. Much simpler than weighing! But maybe I'm missing out on some serious chili bargains. Food for thought, I guess.
normalised: I even saw someone buying green chilies in "pao", that's two hundred and fifty gram, right? I usually just buy a small packet for rupee ten or rupee twenty. Much simpler than weighing! But maybe I'm missing out on some serious chili bargains. Food for thought, I guess.

unnormalised: Buying spices can be confusing too! So many recipes call for "1 tsp of turmeric powder" or "½ tsp of chili powder". Those tiny little spoon measurements! I swear, sometimes I just eyeball it and hope for the best. But then my food ends up either too bland or too spicy. I need to invest in a proper measuring spoon set, I think. I need to get "1 tbsp" sorted out.
normalised: Buying spices can be confusing too! So many recipes call for "one teaspoon of turmeric powder" or "half teaspoon of chili powder". Those tiny little spoon measurements! I swear, sometimes I just eyeball it and hope for the best. But then my food ends up either too bland or too spicy. I need to invest in a proper measuring spoon set, I think. I need to get "one tablespoon" sorted out.

unnormalised: It's funny how something as simple as grocery shopping can turn into a math lesson. But I'm actually enjoying the challenge. It's making me more aware of what I'm buying and how much I'm using. And who knows, maybe I'll even become a master of vegetable measurement someday!
normalised: It's funny how something as simple as grocery shopping can turn into a math lesson. But I'm actually enjoying the challenge. It's making me more aware of what I'm buying and how much I'm using. And who knows, maybe I'll even become a master of vegetable measurement someday!

unnormalised: So, next time you're at the *mandi*, take a moment to appreciate the units of measurement all around you. And maybe bring a small weighing scale... just in case! Let me know if you have any *desi* measurement tips! I'm always looking for new ways to improve my *sabzi* shopping game! And also, do you call it "kg" or "kilo"? Because I switch between the two!
